awd_titl_txt: Harnessing Gesture and Action to Improve Pre-Algebra Instruction
awd_abstract_narration:
Students who succeed in algebra are more likely to be successful in advanced STEM courses. Students who fail algebra are more likely to drop out of high school. A team of researchers at the University of Chicago and Loyola University Chicago will conduct a set of experimental studies to explore how gesture and use of manipulatives may improve understanding of mathematical equivalence. a fundamental, pre-algebraic building block. Young children often have misconceptions about this concept??they can correctly solve problems like 3+4+5=___ , but when faced with a problem like 3+4+5=___+5, they add all of the numbers together, or just add the numbers to the left of the equal sign. This misconception often leads to difficulties with algebra. The researchers will test how two forms of movement that students and teachers already use in a classroom setting can be used to improve learning outcomes: actions, performed directly on objects, and gestures, movements of the hands that can communicate ideas along with speech. Previous work shows that both action and gesture have powerful effects on how children think and learn. Through a series of studies, the research team will explore (1) how children learn, generalize, and retain an understanding of mathematical equivalence after learning through action or gesture, (2) how spoken instruction can be used with action and gesture to affect learning outcomes, and (3) how action and gesture can be combined in instruction to bolster learning. To motivate future work and refine educational practices, behavioral methods and neuroimaging techniques will be used to understand how action and gesture produce their effects. By considering how the brain changes over the course of learning, it will be possible to gain a clearer understanding of the aspects of gesture and action that should be emphasized in the creation of teaching tools. The project is funded by the EHR Core Research program, which supports fundamental research that advances the research literature on STEM learning.

The overarching goal of the research is to investigate how action and gesture instruction affect children?s ability to learn, generalize, and retain information relevant to developing the pre-algebraic concept of mathematical equivalence. Action and gesture are both powerful tools that can shape cognition. However, these tools may promote learning in different ways and thus may be beneficial at different stages of the learning process. The supported projects explore this hypothesis, and have 3 specific goals:  (1) To determine how action and gesture can best be used not only to promote initial learning of mathematical equivalence, but also to promote generalization and retention of the newly learned concept. The effects of action and gesture training will be considered on both a behavioral and neural level. Behavioral data will indicate general outcomes; neuroimaging methods will be used to differentiate between various mechanisms that could underlie the behavioral effects. Combining these methods will lead to the development of evidence-based educational techniques that target learning through action and gesture. (2) To determine how action and gesture interact with spoken instruction to promote learning, generalization, and retention of mathematical equivalence.  Spoken instruction is the most common instructional method used by teachers, and prior work suggests that gesture is more tightly integrated with speech than action. Understanding how speech interacts with gesture and action to promote learning thus has the potential to increase the utility of each of these teaching tools. (3) To determine how gesture and action can be combined to promote learning, generalization and retention of mathematical equivalence. Action may be a useful way to introduce a concept; gesture may encourage children to generalize the concept. This issue takes on importance because of the frequency with which actions on manipulatives are used in classrooms; although good at introducing learners to a concept, manipulatives may have an important downside: They may inhibit generalization to new problems. These goals will be addressed through research with 9-10 year old children in a series of between-group studies.

por.por_cntn:
Mastering algebra is a gateway to academic success. But to master algebra, students must develop foundational understanding of pre-algebraic concepts, long before they enter an algebra classroom. One fundamental pre-algebraic concept that students struggle with is mathematical equivalence - the idea that two sides of an equation need to be equivalent. The purpose of this grant was to explore how tools already used by teachers in classrooms can be harnessed to teach mathematical equivalence more effectively, particularly children from low income homes, and thus put children on a more equal playing field for learning algebra and higher-level mathematics. The tools we focused on were: (1) the actions performed directly on objects (known as manipulatives) that are frequently used in mathematics classrooms, and (2) the co-speech gestures that frequently accompany instruction in mathematics classrooms. Action and gesture are both powerful tools that can shape learning. However, these tools may help learners in different ways. Our project had three main goals: (1) To compare the impact of gesture vs. action on learning, generalization, and retention, and to explore the mechanisms underlying these effects. (2) To determine how gesture vs. action interacts with spoken instruction to promote learning, generalization, and retention. (3) To explore whether gesture and action can be effectively used together in instruction, and whether the order in which they are presented in a lesson affects learning.

Through our work, we now know how to more effectively use gesture and action to support learning of mathematical equivalence. First, we have a better grasp of the mechanisms by which gestures produced by a teacher and gestures produced by a learner support student learning. When students see a teacher gesture, that gesture does more than show them where to look. It helps students coordinate their attention with a teacher's speech and understand spoken instruction that may otherwise be confusing (Wakefield et al., 2018). When students do gestures themselves, gesture might help for a different reason: Using neuroimaging, we found that when children produce gestures while learning and then solve problems without gesture while their brain activity is measured, they nevertheless recruit motor regions of the brain - this does not happen if children learned without gesture (Wakefield et al., 2019). This pattern of brain activation is similar to the activation that occurs when we learn through our own actions on objects, such as when we learn to write letters or play a musical instrument. Thus, the act of gesturing may support learning because it involves the body directly in the learning process.

A second important outcome of our work sheds light on how gesture and spoken instruction interact to promote learning. Taken together, our findings on mechanism suggest that the relation between speech and gesture may be more important for shaping learning when a teacher is producing gesture, than when a student produces gesture, and that is what we find: When children see a teacher gesture, gesture presented at the same time with spoken instruction is more effective for learning than gesture presented after spoken instruction (Congdon et al., 2017). However, when children do a gesture strategy and produce a second strategy in speech, whether or not gesture and speech are produced at the same time does not matter for learning (Carrazza et al., 2021). Interestingly, when children learn through self-produced action and speech, they benefited the most from producing action and speech at the same time. These findings have practical implications for using gesture and action in the classroom.

A third important outcome of our work relates to combining gesture and action to support instruction.  In terms of overarching effects of gesture and action, we have replicated and extended previous work to show that gesture is an overall better tool than action for both flexible learning (Congdon et al., in prep) and retention (Kersey et al., in revision). However, we also found that when combining gesture and action instruction, it is better for children with less implicit understanding of mathematical equivalence to produce action followed by gesture than to produce gesture followed by action, suggesting that action may be a useful stepping stone in the initial stages of learning (Kersey et al., in revision). And this is just one of many instances we have uncovered of individual differences that affect a child's likelihood to learn from gesture and action. Overall, our results add to the recommendations we can make to classroom teachers, as well as deepening our understanding of the boundaries and nuances of the effects of gesture and action on math equivalence learning. We know now that there are differences in how gesture and action impact learning when they are produced versus observed, that the relation to spoken instruction is important to consider, and that a child's prior knowledge must also be considered when deciding on appropriate instruction.
